ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture on thursday and recorded lecture on tuesday.
One day it was live virtual lecture, another day it was pre-recorded videos.
It was an almost even split between recorded lectures and live virtual lectures. (Once a week each)
We had one Lecture live every week, and one lecture pre-recorded.
Thursday Live Sessions for those interested.
recorded and live combo
and recorded lecture
Live lecture and recorded lecture
Recorded lectures for Tuesday, synchronous learning/lecture on Thursday
It was 50% recorded lectures and 50% live virtual lectures.
Virtual lecture live on Thursday, recorded content for Tuesdays.
A combination of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures
Class was a combination of live remote lectures and recorded remote lectures
recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, study halls
Prerecorded lectures on Tuesday, live on Thursday
Half asynchronous lectures, half synchronous
The lectures were also recorded.
live virtual lecture
Asynchronous recorded lectures and one live lecture a week.
Recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
There were recorded lectures for Tuesdays and live lectures on Thursdays
synchronous and asynchronous
Recorded lectures and live virtual lectures
Mix of live and recorded lecture
Courses were taught synchronously but recorded for an asynchronous option.
There were some recorded lectures as well.
One recorded lecture and one live lecture per week.
recorded and live virtual lecture
We had class Tues and Thurs. Tues was optional office hours style because we had pre recorded lecture videos instead of live on Tuesdays. Thursdays we had live lecture.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture
recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Office Hours
Asynchronous videos and one live lecture that is recorded and posted afterwards
Half of lectures were recorded to be watched asynchronously.
A mix of half live lectures and half recorded lectures.
I also attended synchronous lectures
Recorded lecture
recorded lecture + live virtual lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great intro to R and recap from AP or intro stats courses.
Mostly how to use R and some useful packages within R.
A good grasp of R and the underlying statistical concepts to get started on analyzing data.
I developed a foundation for programming in R and a basic understanding of statistical analysis.
Learned some elementary statistics skills as well as how to use R to apply those statistics to large data sets.
how to use R and basic stats knowledge
Learned R, lots of statistics and data science/analysis

I learned how to use the R programming language to conduct exploratory data analysis and run various statistical tests. I learned how to fit models and test their robustness, create graphics (including maps and regression lines), and use LaTex. We also explored more conceptual statistical topics, such as Principal Component Analysis, ANOVA, and multiple linear regression.
I learned how to use R and analyze data in this program.
I got a lot better at R and learned some statistical analysis.
I learned about how to use R and a bunch of statistical concepts
I learned an introductory level of R coding: manipulating data frames and data forms, wrangling data, and using statistical procedures in R

This class was a nice overview of a few intro statistics concepts, but most importantly, it was an introduction to R, and a darn good one. I came out of this feeling ready for data science as a reality/application

I developed a strong foundation of R language, and got pretty familiar with R Studio. I also was refreshed on many statistical concepts, as well as introduced to some new ones like machine learning. I was able to apply these concepts to actual datasets, and run different kinds of tests on them. Graphs and visualizations were incorporated throughout.
Learning R and using it to wrangle, analyze and visualize data.
Basic understanding of R, fast paced coding skills

Reinforcement of introductory statistics concepts
Advanced data analysis techniques including bootstrap method and data wrangling
How to use R
How to create visually appealing data representations
Basics of R coding.
I developed a strong working knowledge of R and how to apply statistical methods within it.
greater understanding of using R
I definitely developed a good grasp of using R to conduct statistical analyses
I learned more statistics concepts and how to use R
Using R and statistic concepts
I learned the general basics of computer science and how to apply statistical tests to computer science in R.
I learned how to use different statistical concepts to analyze data and to use R to appropriately visualize this analysis.
I learned to use the R coding language, and I solidified my understanding of many statistical concepts and techniques.

I reviewed intro stats concepts and learned how to use R programming language. I improved on my stats skills by learning PCA, clustering, multiple linear  regression and non-parametric hypothesis tests.
Stats analysis! Super helpful course
I learned a ton of R, like how to wrangle data, run hypothesis tests, make data visualizations, among other things. I also got to learn more about statistics conceptually and then apply it in R.
review of introductory statistics concepts, knowledge of foundational statistical tests and concepts, practice with visual representation of data, strong preparation in using the program R
How to code in r and various statistical exploration and testing methods
Statistical tests for significance, ways to predict future data, other broad statistical ideas/concepts, also lots of R programming
Statistic concepts, coding in R.

It's mostly an R class. There are central statistics concepts - mostly revolving around various types of hypothesis testing - but in terms of things that are certain to be new to you, it's an R class.
I learned the programming language R and how to use it within statistical methods.
I learned how to be familiar with R and how to research answers to questions I ran into. I also gained more familiarity with basic statistical concepts
I learned a lot about data analysis and coding in R. I feel it increased my knowledge in the data science field, which is what I was hoping for.
Stronger R skills

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course does a good job when explaining topics, but we constantly ran out of time in lecture because lecture became a place to ask questions about the recorded material. The live lecture should not have spent any time answering questions about previous material.

-Strengths: very focused on R and coding so you can get very comfortable with the programming language.
-Weaknesses: not very thorough with the statistical concepts and understanding when to use certain tests.

Strengths: allows for people of different backgrounds to learn about stats regardless of previous preparation, which is cool because data analysis is relevant to pretty much all disciplines.
Weaknesses: large virtual lectures can sometimes be challenging because of a lot of questions with the added difficulty of concentrating on Zoom, etc.

Strength: Good coverage of how to use R, especially in regards to analyzing data sets
Weakness: Coverage of material at the end of the course was a little quick, and didn't dive into the content as much as I would've liked
I really liked the asynchronous classes and how well organized it was. The final project was super fun- I wish there were more opportunities for group work.
Think overall it's a really good course. My only issues were that it was sometimes disorganized and there was a lack of information about how assignments were graded or details around the final.

The strength of this course lied in the TAs and instructor. Prof Meyers was pretty personable, even with 100+ people taking the class. The TA office hours were comprehensive and informative. R is an incredibly useful language to know. The weakness would be the reliance on Piazza for student participation. I preferred talking with other students and the professor in office hours and during the optional Tuesday sessions.

I enjoyed the problem sets as they were fruitful and helped me learn. I however found them to be very long and arduous, especially since I had no one to work them with. Additionally, the midterm & exam were very poorly administered, as they relied on students having new computers and access to strong wifi at all times. The workload was far greater than any other classes.

A big strength was the sense of community among the students. So many people participated over Zoom through the chat, on Piazza, and in groupchats, in a friendly and helpful way. A weakness was that the midterm exam was brutal, given in too short a time span, and not at all representative of the psets or what we focused on in class. The R content overall was better than the statistics content.

One of the strengths was that I felt very supported in the class the whole time. I appreciated how there was a lot of office hours and really dedicated TAs/ULAs that were always willing to happen. I also liked the combination of synchronous and asynchronous material of the class.

Strengths: Personally I enjoyed the professor's teaching and I thought he was very reasonable with expectations given the pandemic. He is very humorous, laid-back, and always willing to help during office hours.
Weaknesses: it is a mixture of grad students and undergrads, so commitment levels and past experience vary widely. A lot of the homeworks focused on coding, so the statistical concept-heavy midterm and final could be a bit difficult. Also, grading on the homeworks was unreasonable at worst or inconsistent at best.

The instructor was always asking for feedback, and honestly, giving participation points for answering questions on Piazza was brilliant. The course was also aggressively staffed, so there were tons of resources for students if they were confused about a topic. This course started off really strong. Towards the latter half of the course, though, there was a little bit of a slump. The midterm really came out of nowhere, and I think the average was something like a 68, but the final was super reasonable.

I liked that Professor Meyers often asked for feedback, and adjusted his class accordingly. The half asynchronous classes were a good balance, since I often found myself speeding up or stopping at certain points. This allowed me to learn at my own pace, whereas in class, often he would get bogged down by answering specific questions from the chat. I liked having one homework assignment per week; I think this was a reasonable amount of work, and showed us how to apply new information to real-life examples. Explaining the code and results in words helped me to better understand each step of the process. I do think this class was not the most engaging, so it was more dependent on the individual student to participate or learn, which was okay with me. However, I found it hard to get to know any of the other students, and there were not many opportunities to collaborate, but again, it ultimately did not affect my education in this course much. We also did not receive that much individual feedback on assignments, but in general, I understood my errors.
Well taught and interesting material, but the midterm was harder and non-reflective of the difficulty of the rest of the class. The final was much better.
Strengths: office hours, recorded lectures; Weaknesses: no review sessions, midterm prep

Strengths: lectures were recorded which was good for review and fitting them into personal schedules as needed. Office hours were offered regularly and were very helpful.

Weaknesses: Homework focused a lot on how to do stuff in R, but exams also covered the finer points of statistics concepts that weren't reinforced much through homework.

Good introduction to coding, but there are many people in the class with varying degrees of coding experience. Should have had better baseline introduction classes for people who have never coded before.

Strengths: teaching of R, TF office hours

Weaknesses: teaching of conceptual topics, structure of examinations.  There was very little teaching of statistical concepts, yet they made up a decently big portion of the exams.
needs a better way to calculate a participation grade than by answering questions on piazza
I think the course overall was great, it really offered a wide span of knowledge from some advanced statistical concepts to using R.
Strengths: organization
Strength: you learn R. Weakness: a lot of material that is quickly went over or is presented at once. While the skills are good, can get very confusing. Grading is also very picky.

This course required a solid background in introductory statistics and often skipped over the statistics review to focus on the coding part. This posed a challenge since many people were at least a year removed from their intro stats class.
This course was very well taught and the concepts seen were very useful.

The course was structured very well. I felt that I learned well from the lectures and got practice of the problem sets. Also there was always a way for me to get my questions answered. The midterm exam was the only part of the course that was not well put together.
Better in person lectures

STRENGTHS: During remote learning, this was a great class because of the balance between asynchronous and synchronous portions of the class. Tuesday's lecture was asynchronous and the actual class time was optional office hours. Thursdays we had live lecture with participation. Professor Meyers is also great, I think he truly cares about his students and the learning. The TAs are also great, shoutout to Duda, Duda is absolutely amazing! I felt like the class was structured to learn and make the material really accessible. The lectures, class code and PSETS were all related to each other and pretty manageable, sometimes even pretty easy if you're comfortable with the material from the lecture. The first exam was easy but the time crunch really made it much more difficult than it was meant to be. The final exam was much better structured. Prof Meyers loves memes and jokes and they bring life to class :) WEAKNESSES: I think time could have been used better. Sometimes the prof spent a lot of time answering questions during class and we wouldn't get through all the material. It wasn't bad bad but it was frustrating at times that the question period was pretty long during lecture. And this isn't per say a weakness but the conceptual parts of the exams can be tricky. Just make sure to study for those pretty well too, not just the code.

The course was very strong in explaining statistical tests and connecting them to central concepts in the fields of statistics and data science. It was also engaging throughout, using interesting and relevant data as well as jokes and humor in the lectures and examples. The course also prepared me very well to use R on my own in the future to analyze data. I think in the later lectures on more advanced concepts didn't seem to connect as well to the earlier concepts we had learned, so it was harder to understand and remember them.
Prof Ethan was rushing all the content towards the end. Also the mid term was given pretty poorly.
I think this course did a good job of balancing the material online and in person. I think that the course could be improved in the amount of material covered.
Weakness was the difficulty of the exams. All PSETs are coding-based, and the exams are half conceptual questions that we don't have practice with. Unfair.

It's adapted pretty well to an online format. The asynchronous lectures feel like they were made to be that way, and Professor Meyers seems to be comfortable lecturing that way.

On the other hand, it's hard to feel engaged with the class. There's not a ton of critical thinking involved (except maybe the final project), and the majority of it is taking code and ideas from the lectures and putting them into the problem sets. (Also, incorrect answers on the exams are worth negative points. Why? Who does that?)
The strenghts were its' trajectory and lectures, the weaknesses was how little person to person interaction there was.

The weaknesses is that the problem sets do not always connect with the exam material, and I felt they were often too simple to reflect real questions one might address when using data science in regular life.
This class teaches very important material and provides the students with great knowledge, though it can be easy for a student to get lost behind without the professor realizing.

Strength - helpful homework psets and office hours, engaging lectures
weakness - testing format: R program was crashing during the midterm and final which was timed. Lost some points because of that (didn't get a chance to finish tests due to technical difficulties). Those should have bene take-home since a lot of students had trouble with that (which would have bene much easier to fix during the test if it was in-person)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The prerecorded lectures were great, but the live lectures were too often a waste of time because too much time was spent answering questions about the prerecorded lectures.
The hybrid live/recorded format was really really nice for this class.
I felt that the asynchronous lectures were great especially when followed up by a live session where the professor did Q&A

Loved the format. Asynchronous and synchronous allowed me to go at my own pace but still have place to ask questions.
Also to clarify, by "loved" I mean that it was great for COVID, a normal semester would be preferred.

I liked the fact that we used real time COVID data during the PSets. I found that the lecture course style translated pretty well to the virtual format. I just wasn't the biggest fan of Piazza as a platform to measure participation.
I enjoyed the recorded content on Tuesdays, but I believe the exams were very poorly run amongst the covid circumstances, given the reliance on newer computers and strong WiFi.

Professor Meyers was very good at facilitating participation in the chat over Zoom, better than any other class I've seen. There was something very camaraderie-inducing about Ethan asking a question and everyone typing the answer into the chat really fast. I also appreciated how everything was accessible on the first pages, especially recorded lectures we had to watch. The R exams implemented over Zoom were somewhat bumpier, but the final was a lot better than the midterm because we had more time and it was partly on Canvas.
I liked the combination of synchronous components with asynchronous components (the fact that it was both live and recorded lectures provided important flexibility).

The homework sets were great since they were coding-based. Office hours with TA's through Zoom and one-to-one debugging sessions were really nice to have. Something that could be improved is the lectures and delivery of material to be more engaging and provide more focus on statistical concepts.
Having a combination of asynchronous and synchronous lectures (and multiple time slots for exams) was perfect

Switching to a half-asynchronous class with an office hours instead was a good fit for this class, as many of the questions seemed to be about individual coding errors. In this way, Zoom was quite useful for sharing screens and identifying issues. I felt well-supported to take this class in my own time, and all the videos and lecture materials were very accessible. I generally felt that I was provided everything I needed to do well in this course, but that I wasn't necessarily required to participate very often. Piazza was quite useful for asking and answering questions.
Half asynchronous and half synchronous. The synchronous lectures were also recorded for those who couldn't attend.
Virtual office hours were a great help. Especially since homework involved coding, screen sharing was an efficient way for peer tutors to give feedback.
Asynchronous learning was very helpful.

I thought that this course transferred particularly well to a virtual format.  The only issue was how the exams worked, especially the midterm.

The midterm was horribly set up and clearly caused a lot of problems for many.  Having a time limit on an exam heavy in coding in a class with many students who are coding for the first time is a recipe for disaster.  The exam was especially unforgiving when it came to knitting errors and simple things that really should not matter on an exam.  This format caused unnecessary stress and really took away from students being able to do what they are meant to be doing on an exam--showing that they know the material.  Much time on the exam was spent trying to fix knitting errors when it could have been spent actually proving knowledge.
I think that the asynchronous lectures were great
The format worked well with one live lecture and other recorded lectures

A timed coding midterm exam was an inappropriate way to test our knowledge and skills learned in the class, as it caused many stressors that were unnecessary. Many students were unhappy with this format because they felt as though they werent given a fair chance to sit with the material in time to produce results, since it was so rushed.
Recorded lectures really helped me understand better concepts by rewinding and pausing the videos whenever I found them confusing.
All of the virtual practices succeeded.
Good recorded videos

Mixture of asynchronous and synchronous class time worked super well! Tuesday lecture was optional and we had asynchronous lecture videos instead. Thursday was live and prof Meyers made it so that we could participate.

I liked the recorded lectures, I was able to take notes on the slides and replay concepts or move quickly through things I felt I understood well. I think the live virtual lectures were good for having questions answered but I preferred the recorded lecture format for introducing new topics.
The recorded lectures were helpful, the live ones were rushed and we didn't finish the content he intended to cover.
I think office hours and recorded lectures were very helpful
PSETs, office hours were very engaging and helpful to understanding the content.

Most of the course felt like it transferred online pretty seamlessly, although the beginning was a bit bumpy. The exams, on the other hand, were not adapted well; it felt like both were not planned out well and were needlessly complex to take.
I think the mix of pre-recorded and live lectures was very good. I don't think much could be improved.
The participation grade for posting on Piazza was unclearly delineated. Clarifying how exactly participation works would improve the course.
I think it was great to mix asynchronous and synchronous lectures. It provides a healthy level of flexibility.

Making a second optional lecture and using that time slot as OH was a great idea. 
Coming up with a better way of midterm/final examination as it was a disaster for some of us living in a loud household with so many things going around and having to deal with program crash during a timed test. A clearer project guideline would also be helpful as it is 10% of the grade.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to get a solid basic understanding of R, this is the course for you.
Not really unless you need to learn R.
Absolutely!
If you want to take one data analysis class during your Yale career I think it should be this one.
This class should not be taken on a lark, if you sign up for this class expect to work hard and still struggle.
If interested in learning R, this is the course for you!
Yes, a great way to learn R is an organized setting
Yeah definitely. Knowing R is a great skill to have and the class is chill.

Yes! If you have a basic understanding of statistics and want to learn practical skills, this is a great course to take. It's a little light on theory (you aren't told why things work---just that they do), but there aare other courses at Yale that cover that.
No, I would not recommend this course to someone else unless there is a different professor than E. Meyers. He was oftentimes rude and unavailable for his students.
Yes, workload isnt that bad, its interesting concepts and good for people who don't have a coding background. Could be kind of boring at times

I would recommend it if you want to get a working knowledge of R supplemented with statistical concepts. You're in the best position if you have a background in basic/intro statistics, like AP statistics.
Take S&DS 230! If you're interested in applications, this is the name of the game.

I found this class very useful and practical. Not only did we learn important statistical concepts, but we applied them to interesting real-life datasets, and examined them for patterns and trends. I appreciated coming out of this course with a strong foundation in R, which I am excited to be able to use in the future. The material is well taught, and the assignments are straightforward, though not necessarily easy. Professor Meyer makes the class fun with his incessant dad jokes! Be aware that this class is about 50/50 statistical concepts and R programming, so if you don't really care for learning R, this might not be the course for you.
Yes - interesting material and useful to learn R.
If you have a solid grasp of introductory statistics concepts, yes. If no background in R or coding, should be willing to put in a lot of effort into becoming familiar with the language.
Yes, especially if you want an introduction into coding that isnt too CS heavy.

I would recommend this class as a great way to learn R.  You will get the most out of the class if you already have a stats background, as the conceptual parts of the class are mostly just reviewed quickly or skipped over altogether.
Fine introduction to R, but so much petty work revising psets to avoid missing points for silly things

Yes! If you want to learn R and dip your toe into statistics, this is a great course for that. The statistical concepts aren't too difficult to grasp and a lot of the class focuses on how to implement the use of statistics with real-life data sets.
yes - fun, and interesting!
No unless youre a Stats major or trying of get the certificate
Depends. If you would like to learn R - yes. But the grading can be harsh and you really need to put in a lot of work. Maybe take it Cr / D, also consider the same course taught in another semester?
I would recommend this course to somehow with a solid background in introductory statistics, or who is willing to do the statistics review on their own.
Yes, this course is very useful and it really helped me find a practical use for statistics and data science.
I found this course challenging but worthwhile so I would recommend it.

Yes! This was a great way to learn R and some of the foundational statistical theory needed to use it. If youre deciding between taking it in the Fall of with JDRS, I would say Ethan is a pretty great guy and theres no need to wait until the spring. Im happy with my choice to take it this semester
Definitely! This is a great class to build upon your stats skills. If your field requires you to know R as well, this class will be perfect for you.
Yes!
I would recommend this course. Overall, it teaches many important statistical concepts quite well and teaches you to apply them to real problems.

Yes! If you want to learn R, regardless of your major, and have some statistics experience/knowledge this course is very manageable and you gain a lot of basic R skills. Prof Meyers is awesome, and the prof and TAs care about your learning. As a humanities major, this course is a great break from all the reading and writing and you learn skills that really could help you in any field!

Yes, this is a great course to take if you are going to be working with data in the future. It gives you a strong grounding in basic statistics and data science concepts, introduces you to the major types of statistical analysis, and helps you learn how to explain and visually represent your analyses. It also prepares you to use the program R, one of the most widely used statistical programs, to analyze data on your own.
Take it in person.
Yes, I think that statistics was something that I effectively learned. I think that I was actually able to remember a good amount of what we learned throughout the semseter

Yes, with caveats. It's not a stellar class, but you'll get the R and data management content you're looking for. The caveats are (1) if you already have programming experience, you're going to find the R parts of class to be very frustrating, and (2) like I've said, the exams are a bit of a mess at the moment.
Yes, it was  a great intro into the world of data science.
I would recommend this course, but only as a Credit/D. It is very time and work intensive, and I feel that a timed exam is a poor reflection of one's understanding of the course material.
Yes, it is a very good introduction to data analysis.
Yes if some of the suggested improvements actually take place.
